findings.title: DoS occurs because relayer does not verify event data
findings.description: Relayer mishandles event data, leading to DoS.

findings.title: RetryEventHandler does not verify the event address, leads to arbitrary deposit
findings.description: The relayer doesn't check whether the address that emitted the Deposit event is equal to the bridge address itself.

findings.title: blockConfirmations can be bypassed
findings.description: An attacker can bypass blockConfirmations by supplying the transaction hash of a transaction that did not occur yet as an input to the retry function.

findings.title: Attacker may always become the coordinator in bully mode
findings.description: The attacker can prolong the coordination process, making every other relayer go into waitForStart, then start the TSS initiate process, which makes the attacker the coordinator.

findings.title: Retry function can be spammed to exhaust relayerâ€™s balance
findings.description: The retry function can be repeatedly called with a failed deposit transaction hash, exhausting the relayer's mainnet token.

findings.title: Documentation does not match implementation in setResource() functions
findings.description: The admin may overwrite contract addresses or resourceIDs by mistake due to incorrect documentation.

findings.title: ERC721Handler can be used to steal other's bridged NFTs
findings.description: Any attacker can steal other's bridged (burnable) NFTs if the user has approved the NFT to the ERC721Handler.

findings.title: Hashing issue in Bridge.sol
findings.description: Malicious attackers may be able to replay signatures if additional modifications are made to the code.

findings.title: TSS process has weak input validation on libp2p peer and message data
findings.description: A malicious relayer can sign any signatures at will due to weak input validation.

findings.title: Other minor documentation flaws exist
findings.description: Various minor mistakes in the documentation.
